content.webTitle: Morning Mail: Reza Barati, Lima climate talks, Abbott on Ukraine, top non-fiction books

fields.headline: Morning Mail: Reza Barati, Lima climate talks, Abbott on Ukraine, top non-fiction books
fields.bodyText: Good morning folks, and welcome to the Morning Mail – sign up here to get it straight to your inbox every weekday morning. Australian news and politics • The violence that killed Reza Barati in the Manus Island detention centre was “eminently foreseeable” and the Australian government is responsible for his death, a parliamentary inquiry has found. Tony Abbott has told Ukraine’s president that Australia could send uranium and coal to help secure the country’s energy sources against Russian threats. The government has established a dedicated taskforce to fly around the world and lobby key countries to ensure the Great Barrier Reef isn’t listed as ‘in danger’ by the UN. The WA and NT governments have rejected the UN committee against torture’s call for mandatory sentencing laws to be abolished because they put too many Indigenous Australians behind bars, as figures show that number has grown by more than 80% in 10 years and the overall imprisonment rate is rising. The freedom of information laws of our entire nation are being watched over by two men working from homeafter the government’s plans to abolish the regulator stalled in the Senate. Around the world • Negotiators working on a deal to fight climate change have agreed on just a single paragraph of text at the Lima climate talks, with only 24 hours left. • After the release of the damning report into torture, the embattled director of the CIA has insisted the agency “did a lot of things right” in a time when there were “no easy answers”, but the Senate intelligence committee chairwoman used Twitter to rebut his statement in real time. • Following the first ever public appeal by Interpol to catch the most-wanted environmental criminals, a suspected ivory smuggler has been arrested in Zambia. • Defiant Hong Kong pro-democracy protesters vow they’ll be back as the main protest site is dismantled, with analysts saying the struggle for voting rights will continue as trust in Beijing erodes. • Police in Madrid are searching for about 70 paintings worth almost $1m after three men walked out of an art gallery with the works. • A teenage suicide bomber has killed a German citizen in an attack on a high school in Kabul, during the performance of a drama condemning suicide attacks. More from around the web • Among the most read on the Guardian this morning: An interactive infographic of the non-fiction books everyone should read. We’ve scraped, collated and summarised a selection of “all-time” book polls, prize-winners and readers’ picks to assemble a visual consensus of the must-read classics of non-fiction. • The vow of celibacy may have contributed to to decades of child sex abuse committed by Catholic priests and clergy,according to a landmark report, The Australian reports. • RBA governor Glenn Stevens wants the dollar to fall to US75¢ - levels last seen a decade ago - and says official interest rate cuts need to be delivered in a way that boosts confidence,the Australian Financial Review reports. • A crackdown on disability support pensions will attempt to flush out ‘rorters’ who try to claim millions of dollars,the Daily Telegraph reports. One last thing The nation stumbles out of whatever it calls bed and they wonder to themselves... How is the government going to stuff up horribly today? First Dog On The Moon captures the essence of the national mood Have an excellent day – and if you spot something I’ve missed, let me know in the comments here or on Twitter @earleyedition.
